awd_titl_txt: Multi-Component Reactive Pressure-dependent Chemistry Verified by Multi-Scale Uncertainty Quantification
awd_abstract_narration:
Emerging combustion engine technologies show promise for improved fuel economy and reduced environmental pollution. However, engineers face design challenges because these improved engines require unprecedentedly precise control of fuel combustion chemistry. Optimal design now requires scientific descriptions of combustion chemistry to be unprecedentedly precise. This is especially true for engineers using computer models. To serve these needs, the project goal is to create and validate predictive combustion chemistry models. This project will create descriptions of combustion chemistry at the molecular level and then validate these descriptions against combustion measurements. The fundamental chemical behavior characterized in this research will also lead to a greater understanding of planetary atmospheres. Finally, this project will bring research discoveries to students in the classroom, train graduate students in state-of-the-art computer modeling, and share the scientific thought process with local K-12 students in school visits and lab tours.

The technical objective of the proposed research is to create a multi-scale, uncertainty-quantified model of H2/CO/CH2O combustion that is consistent with both first principles and combustion experiments. A primary focus is establishing the types of phenomenological reactions and rate laws of highly reactive engine environments, especially for non-thermal kinetic sequences that have complex dependences on temperature, pressure, and mixture composition. The PI proposes to 1) perform state-of-the-art first principles calculations for important non-thermal kinetic sequences; 2) construct a multi-scale combustion model that directly bridges molecular behavior, calculable from first principles, to macroscopic behavior, measurable in combustion experiments; and 3) test model consistency with both first principles and combustion experiments to validate the model via inverse uncertainty quantification. By the project end, the established reaction types and rate laws will serve as prototypes for other reactions in combustion and atmospheres, and the produced high-accuracy model will be ready to use in other scientific and engineering applications.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE TRUSTEES OF COLUMBIA UNIVERSITY IN THE CITY OF NEW YORK

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Emerging combustion engine technologies show promise for improved fuel economy and reduced environmental pollution. However, engineers face design challenges because these improved engines require unprecedentedly precise control of fuel combustion chemistry. Optimal design now requires scientific descriptions of combustion chemistry, likewise, to be unprecedentedly precise. This is especially true for engineers using computer models.

To serve these needs, the goal of this project was to enable predictive combustion modeling, by establishing descriptions of combustion chemistry at the molecular level and then validating these descriptions against macroscopic combustion measurements.  In particular, the research activities centered on the creation of a multiscale, uncertainty-quantified model of H2/CO/CH2O combustion consistent with both first principles and combustion experiments.  A primary emphasis was to establish a fundamental understanding of chemical reactions in highly reactive environments (such as those of engines), where the large fractions of many inert and reactive species present give rise to non-thermal kinetic sequences whose behavior is inadequately captured in previous macroscopic models.  This project also brought research discoveries to students in the classroom, trained graduate students in state-of-the-art computer modeling, and shared the scientific thought process with local K-12 students in lab tours.

Intellectual Merits:

State-of-the-art first-principles calculations were performed that advanced both qualitative understanding and quantitative predictions of highly reactive chemical environments, where the rovibrationally excited complexes that mediate pressure-dependent reactions collide with many inert and reactive species as "third bodies."   Our theoretical studies revealed the dependence of a recently discovered reaction type, chemically termolecular reactions, on mole fractions of reactive species and pressure for the first time.  Dynamic correction procedures were developed to represent the resulting dependence of their rates on thermodynamic conditions in macroscopic modeling (despite inability of present reacting flow codes to adequately represent them), which enables future macroscopic modeling to account for the important manifestations of these commonly neglected molecular processes.  Furthermore, our studies revealed deficiencies in previous interpretations and common techniques for measuring third-body collision efficiencies of inert species in mixtures, which will lead to better design of experiments and data analysis/reporting procedures for experimental determination of third-body efficiencies.

The MultiScale Informatics (MSI) software for multiscale uncertainty quantification was significantly extended to improve user-friendliness, facilitate scalability to larger datasets, extend the range of capabilities, and include only open-source codes as dependencies -- enabling both full combustion model development and broader adoption of the software.  Accompanying applications of this new code led to new insights on key chemical reactions and contributed to development of multiscale, uncertainty-quantified models for foundational fuel combustion, which advance predictive combustion modeling abilities.

Broader impacts:

The established understanding of chemical reactions in highly reactive environments contributes to current understanding and predictive tools for gas-phase chemical reactions of broad interest to improving combustion engine efficiencies, reducing production of harmful combustion by-products, and understanding the evolution of compounds in planetary atmospheres, including those that influence local air quality and global climate on Earth.  Likewise, the improved methodologies for multiscale uncertainty quantification of chemical systems advance predictive modeling tools for combustion and atmospheric chemistry.  Furthermore, the two graduate students and two undergraduate students involved in the project have gained research experience and skills in computational modeling, theoretical kinetics, combustion kinetics, and code development; and the graduate students who mentored the undergraduate students gained useful management and teaching experience.  Course content in undergraduate/graduate courses has also been updated to reflect recent research discoveries across the field.  Additionally, course assignments were developed to incorporate computational modeling and foster development of scientific thinking skills, including "self-checking."  Finally, students from local NYC K-12 schools gained exposure to scientific careers and the scientific thought process through visits to the PI's laboratory as part of Columbia's Inside Engineering program.

 


Last Modified: 11/30/2021
Modified by: Michael P Burke
